Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Transcutaneous Electrical Acupoint Stimulation for PONV Prevention in Gynecological Laparoscopy

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 120 women, aged 18-65, undergoing gynecological laparoscopy were randomized into three groups

Participants.evidence: This prospective, randomized, double-blind trial was conducted at an academic medical center specializing in women's and children's care. A total of 120 women, aged 18-65, undergoing gynecological laparoscopy

Intervention.evidence: randomized into three groups: single-period TEAS (Group S, n=40), multiple-period TEAS (Group M, n=40), and non-stimulation control (Group C, n=40)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy of single-period versus multiple-period transcutaneous electrical acupoint stimulation (TEAS) for PONV prevention.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was PONV incidence and severity within 48 hours post-surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was computer-generated with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 120 women, aged 18-65, undergoing gynecological laparoscopy were randomized into three groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: Group M showed significantly reduced PONV incidence compared to Group C (10% vs. 50%, p<0.05) and Group S (10% vs. 17.5%, p<0.05).

Harms.evidence: No adverse events related to TEAS were reported.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration: Chinese Clinical Trials Registry, No. ChiCTR2200065802.
